title: 104_s1262
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Products Control Act of 1995" amends the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act by adding new advertising restrictions after section 6. The Tobacco Products Control Act of 1995 prohibits cigarette advertising on outdoor billboards within 500 feet of schools, with exceptions for billboards facing away from schools or at street level near tobacco retailers. It also restricts cigarette ads in publications where more than 15% of readers are under 18 years old. The Tobacco Products Control Act of 1995 prohibits cigarette advertising in certain locations, including outdoor billboards near schools and in publications with a high percentage of underage readers. Additionally, the Act prohibits cigarette placement in movies, video games, and family amusement centers. The definition of amusement devices includes vehicles or structures that provide amusement, pleasure, thrills, or excitement to passengers. Excluded from this definition are coin-operated amusement devices for up to 2 individuals, devices regulated by specific authorities, tractor pulls, auto or motorcycle events, horse shows, rodeos, and other animal shows. The term 'video game' refers to electronic amusement devices utilizing computer circuitry and interacting with the user. The Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986 is amended to include new advertising restrictions. The Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986 is amended to include new advertising restrictions. It is now unlawful to advertise smokeless tobacco products on outdoor billboards within 500 feet of schools, with exceptions for billboards on interstate highways not visible from schools and those at street level near tobacco retailers. Additionally, advertising in periodicals is also prohibited. The Federal Trade Commission will list publications where tobacco products cannot be advertised if more than 15% of readers are under 18. Smokeless tobacco products cannot be placed in motion pictures or video games, and their brand names or logos cannot be displayed in family amusement centers. The term 'family amusement center' refers to an establishment that provides entertainment through amusement rides or attractions. An 'amusement ride or attraction' includes mechanized devices or structures that offer amusement, pleasure, thrills, or excitement to individuals. This definition excludes coin-operated amusement devices for up to two individuals. The curr_chunk defines 'video game' as an electronic amusement device utilizing computer circuitry and a cathode ray tube, designed for use with a television or monitor, and interacting with the user. The curr_chunk amends the Public Health Service Act. The Public Health Service Act is amended to prohibit the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and restrict the operation of vending machines selling tobacco products. The sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 is prohibited, and vending machines selling tobacco products are restricted unless under direct supervision or in specific locations like private clubs, bars, or certain workplaces with minimal underage employees. It is illegal to distribute cigarettes or smokeless tobacco products for free or through redeemable coupons for commercial purposes, except in specific locations permitted by state law. The distribution of cigarettes or smokeless tobacco products through coupons is allowed in specific locations where individuals can prove they are at least 18 years old. In subsections (a)(2) and (c) of the law, the dates for certain percentages are updated to later years, increasing the allowed percentages for distribution of tobacco products. In subsections (a)(2) and (c) of the law, the dates for certain percentages are updated to later years, increasing the allowed percentages for distribution of tobacco products. Additionally, enforcement of laws through grants and a definition for "private club" are added. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include a new section prohibiting the Food and Drug Administration from regulating tobacco products in any way.
